description: King City nursing Mala of Barton built the Krishna Temple in Mangal Bazar of Patan in the courtyard of Patton Palace. It was built around 1693 Bikram Sambad. The temple was established as a copy of another Hindu temple of Lord Krishna present in Mathura in India by City nursing Mala Patan. The temple is entirely built with stone and does not contain wood or bronze for any kind of support. It is also said that the entire Temple was built with one stone alone. There is an interesting reason behind placing the idols of Siva and Krishna in the same Temple. Towards the end of the 17th century, there was a boost on the site of the present Krishna Temple. This land was prepared to build for Siva's temple. Legend says that Krishna Temple was inspired by a dream. One night, gangster the nursing Mala dreamed that the gods Krishna and Radha were standing in front of the palace, so the king ordered a temple built on the same location. According to the legend, an idol of Lord Krishna was found while cutting down a bush. Since the police were the idol of Krishna was found and the land allotted for the Sivalaya was set aside, City nursing started worshiping the idols of Siva and Krishna. Religious gangster the nursing Mala used to perform heaven in the years Nakunda regularly. Even on the day he dreamed, the smoke that came out during the same heaven took the sip of the present Krishna Temple. It is believed that the temple was built in the seeker's child on the same basis. Generally, most of the temples in Nepal are built in Pagoda Style, but this is built in Seeker Style and one can see the influence of Dravidian and Mughal style also. It took six and a half years to build this Temple. This Temple is considered to be a very rare type with a total of 21 gujures. The 21 gujures in Krishna Temple also have different meanings. During the regular heaven after King City nursing Mala, 21 Ernst were installed. The name of the urns was also different; however, the name of the urns is not mentioned in the inscription of the Temple. It is believed that 21 Godzillas were made to represent the urn after the same earn was born in the yazna. This Temple is made of stone and has 21 gujures, which is the most in Nepal. During a war with the neighboring Kingdom at the cat later, the King City nursing Mala emerged victorious after calling on Krishna to vanquish his enemies. In gratitude, the king built a replica of the temple inside the Sundaricho courtyard. Outside the temple is a statue of 10 incarnations of Lord Vishnu. There is a statue of the first incarnation in the east corner, and the idols of various incarnations of God Vishnu are placed in the clockwise direction. On the first floor of the temple, one can see the carved image and script depicting the events of Mahabharata, and the second floor has a carving depicting the Ramayana. The first floor has Krishna, the second Siva in the form of linga, and the third location. Among its three floors, there is a statue of Sri Krishna on the middle floor. There are 10 avatars of Vishnu around the statue of Krishna. This area is listed as a World Heritage Site. In front of this Temple, there is a statue of Garuda, the mount of Vishnu, kneeling with outstretched arms on top of a pillar facing the temple, and on the back of the statue of Garuda is Kotihu Manda. Non-Hindus are prohibited from entering the temple. Every year, a huge number of worshipers throng the temple during the Festival of Krishna's birthday held in August-September.
